values.description:
This is a massive pull request for all my work on the GUI plugin so far.

Until [my pull request in Gazebo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1252/guiiface-reads-gazebo_gui_ini_path/diff) for setting gui.ini gets merged, you'll need to set ~/.gazebo/gui.ini to see the GUI overlay:
~~~
[overlay_plugins]
filenames=libHaptixGUIPlugin.so
~~~
^this will only find the plugin after handsim has been installed.

Pending: pull request for the correct arat.world file with the APL arm, once I test it a bit more.
values.title: Added GUI plugin and config files

values.description:
Two main things:

* listen to gazebo topic for spacenav input instead of directly polling libspnav
* fix rotation math for arm (~~requires gazebo branch [quat_integrate](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/branches/compare/quat_integrate..gazebo_4.0#diff), which I merged into `haptix_scpeters`~~ now available in haptix branch).

You can test at my desk if you like.
values.title: Fix spacenav control of arm

summary.raw:
Two main things:

* listen to gazebo topic for spacenav input instead of directly polling libspnav
* fix rotation math for arm (~~requires gazebo branch [quat_integrate](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/branches/compare/quat_integrate..gazebo_4.0#diff), which I merged into `haptix_scpeters`~~ now available in haptix branch).

You can test at my desk if you like.
summary.html:
Two main things:

  • listen to gazebo topic for spacenav input instead of directly polling libspnav
  • fix rotation math for arm (requires gazebo branch quat_integrate, which I merged into haptix_scpeters now available in haptix branch).

You can test at my desk if you like.

values.description:
While testing different build types (see #2) I came across a compiler warning in `polhemus_driver`, which becomes a hard failure due to `-Werror`.

~~~
[ 25%] Building C object CMakeFiles/polhemus_driver.dir/src/polhemus_driver.c.o
/home/scpeters/ws/handsim/src/handsim/polhemus_driver/src/polhemus_driver.c: In function ‘polhemus_get_pose’:
/home/scpeters/ws/handsim/src/handsim/polhemus_driver/src/polhemus_driver.c:226:12: error: ‘len’ may be used uninitialized in this function [-Werror=maybe-uninitialized]
   buf[len] = '\0';
            ^
/home/scpeters/ws/handsim/src/handsim/polhemus_driver/src/polhemus_driver.c: In function ‘polhemus_get_poses’:
/home/scpeters/ws/handsim/src/handsim/polhemus_driver/src/polhemus_driver.c:250:7: error: ‘len’ may be used uninitialized in this function [-Werror=maybe-uninitialized]
   int len;
       ^
cc1: all warnings being treated as errors

~~~
values.title: Fix polhemus_driver warning, which causes build failure (-Werror) when build type is RelWithDebInfo

values.description:
Add support for receiving `haptix-comm/hxGrasp` messages and executing predefined grasps, including mode-switching between "grasp mode" and "direct motor mode."   The grasp configuration is read from the URDF/SDF (related PR forthcoming in `handsim-proprietary` with some configurations).

Also, @hsu added support here for pausing Polhemus updates, to make it easier to use.

The changes here are difficult to test at the moment.  Your best bet is to try the `move_grasps_to_control_plugin` branch (into which these changes have been merged), and play with the keyboard teleop features provided there.  The changes on that branch will be mostly discarded, in favor of the forthcoming new GUI plugin.
values.title: Add predefined grasps, and polhemus pausing

summary.raw:
Add support for receiving `haptix-comm/hxGrasp` messages and executing predefined grasps, including mode-switching between "grasp mode" and "direct motor mode."   The grasp configuration is read from the URDF/SDF (related PR forthcoming in `handsim-proprietary` with some configurations).

Also, @hsu added support here for pausing Polhemus updates, to make it easier to use.

The changes here are difficult to test at the moment.  Your best bet is to try the `move_grasps_to_control_plugin` branch (into which these changes have been merged), and play with the keyboard teleop features provided there.  The changes on that branch will be mostly discarded, in favor of the forthcoming new GUI plugin.
summary.html:
Add support for receiving haptix-comm/hxGrasp messages and executing predefined grasps, including mode-switching between "grasp mode" and "direct motor mode." The grasp configuration is read from the URDF/SDF (related PR forthcoming in handsim-proprietary with some configurations).

Also, @hsu added support here for pausing Polhemus updates, to make it easier to use.

The changes here are difficult to test at the moment. Your best bet is to try the move_grasps_to_control_plugin branch (into which these changes have been merged), and play with the keyboard teleop features provided there. The changes on that branch will be mostly discarded, in favor of the forthcoming new GUI plugin.

values.description:
It loads gazebo as a background process with the arat world and then tries to spawn the apl arm. It took some trickery to identify the case in which the arm fails to load, since the `gz model` command returns zero, and the failure happens on the server side (I think this would have to be a service call or request/response to give proper feedback to the `gz model` call). To check that the model is spawned correctly, it uses `gz model -i` and counts the number of visuals, since a failure will create an almost empty model with the specified name.

Also, the script passes all arguments to the `gazebo` call, so you can do things like the following:
~~~
handsim_apl --verbose
handsim_apl -u
handsim_apl -e bullet # probably won't work
~~~
values.title: Add startup script for handsim with APL arm

summary.raw:
It loads gazebo as a background process with the arat world and then tries to spawn the apl arm. It took some trickery to identify the case in which the arm fails to load, since the `gz model` command returns zero, and the failure happens on the server side (I think this would have to be a service call or request/response to give proper feedback to the `gz model` call). To check that the model is spawned correctly, it uses `gz model -i` and counts the number of visuals, since a failure will create an almost empty model with the specified name.

Also, the script passes all arguments to the `gazebo` call, so you can do things like the following:
~~~
handsim_apl --verbose
handsim_apl -u
handsim_apl -e bullet # probably won't work
~~~
summary.html:
It loads gazebo as a background process with the arat world and then tries to spawn the apl arm. It took some trickery to identify the case in which the arm fails to load, since the gz model command returns zero, and the failure happens on the server side (I think this would have to be a service call or request/response to give proper feedback to the gz model call). To check that the model is spawned correctly, it uses gz model -i and counts the number of visuals, since a failure will create an almost empty model with the specified name.

Also, the script passes all arguments to the gazebo call, so you can do things like the following:

handsim_apl --verbose
handsim_apl -u
handsim_apl -e bullet # probably won't work

values.description:
Notes:

* This PR requires Gazebo built from the `haptix_gui` branch (not to get the GUI plugin from there, but to use the changes that were made to Gazebo).

This PR moves the HaptixGUIPlugin from Gazebo back into handsim.  Had it stayed in Gazebo, it would have created a dependency from Gazebo on haptix-comm, to access the ignition-transport messages that it uses.

So what we have here is:

* @nkoenig 's new GUI
* plus a cleaned up rewrite of @jacquelinekay 's and my keyboard teleop

Note that we should now use the `arat.world` that's in here.  I've been launching Gazebo as:

    gazebo --verbose install/share/haptix_gazebo_plugins/worlds/arat.world

There might be a better way to handle that path.

It's working for me pretty much as before, though I made a couple of tweaks to the grasp mode switching.
values.title: Redo of teleop in GUI plugin

summary.raw:
Notes:

* This PR requires Gazebo built from the `haptix_gui` branch (not to get the GUI plugin from there, but to use the changes that were made to Gazebo).

This PR moves the HaptixGUIPlugin from Gazebo back into handsim.  Had it stayed in Gazebo, it would have created a dependency from Gazebo on haptix-comm, to access the ignition-transport messages that it uses.

So what we have here is:

* @nkoenig 's new GUI
* plus a cleaned up rewrite of @jacquelinekay 's and my keyboard teleop

Note that we should now use the `arat.world` that's in here.  I've been launching Gazebo as:

    gazebo --verbose install/share/haptix_gazebo_plugins/worlds/arat.world

There might be a better way to handle that path.

It's working for me pretty much as before, though I made a couple of tweaks to the grasp mode switching.
summary.html:
Notes:

  • This PR requires Gazebo built from the haptix_gui branch (not to get the GUI plugin from there, but to use the changes that were made to Gazebo).

This PR moves the HaptixGUIPlugin from Gazebo back into handsim. Had it stayed in Gazebo, it would have created a dependency from Gazebo on haptix-comm, to access the ignition-transport messages that it uses.

So what we have here is:

  • @nkoenig 's new GUI
  • plus a cleaned up rewrite of @jacquelinekay 's and my keyboard teleop

Note that we should now use the arat.world that's in here. I've been launching Gazebo as:

gazebo --verbose install/share/haptix_gazebo_plugins/worlds/arat.world

There might be a better way to handle that path.

It's working for me pretty much as before, though I made a couple of tweaks to the grasp mode switching.

values.description: I removed the round_tin_base model from arat.world. It turns out that it's really hard to pick up the marble when it's in the tin, even though the tin is there to prevent the marble from rolling away. This is a fix for issue #8.

values.description:
side note: you will need to either change your udev rules or your permissions for the hydra to install properly.

you can follow the instructions [here](http://www.gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=hydra&cat=user_input)

or you can do the quick and dirty way:
sudo chmod 666 /dev/hidraw*

values.description:
Re-ordered grasp key bindings in a more user-friendly manner.

Grasp keys:

1. Spherical (works best for the first task, grasping to block)

2. Cylindrical (works best for the second task, gripping the cup)

3. "British" pinch (works best for the third task, pinching the marble--I'd like to just call it "Pinch")

The other 4 grasps are less important, but they'll be kept in for showing-off purposes:

4. "American" pinch

5. "3-finger" pinch

6. Palmar/Tray

7. Hook

I also reordered direct motor control to be more intuitive (so it's easier for us to tune grasps).

1 - 3: thumb controls

4 - 7: bend finger joints

8: thumb mcp (not very useful)

9 - +: finger AB/AD (also not very useful)
values.title: Key binding changes

summary.raw:
Re-ordered grasp key bindings in a more user-friendly manner.

Grasp keys:

1. Spherical (works best for the first task, grasping to block)

2. Cylindrical (works best for the second task, gripping the cup)

3. "British" pinch (works best for the third task, pinching the marble--I'd like to just call it "Pinch")

The other 4 grasps are less important, but they'll be kept in for showing-off purposes:

4. "American" pinch

5. "3-finger" pinch

6. Palmar/Tray

7. Hook

I also reordered direct motor control to be more intuitive (so it's easier for us to tune grasps).

1 - 3: thumb controls

4 - 7: bend finger joints

8: thumb mcp (not very useful)

9 - +: finger AB/AD (also not very useful)
summary.html:
Re-ordered grasp key bindings in a more user-friendly manner.

Grasp keys:

  1. Spherical (works best for the first task, grasping to block)

  2. Cylindrical (works best for the second task, gripping the cup)

  3. "British" pinch (works best for the third task, pinching the marble--I'd like to just call it "Pinch")

The other 4 grasps are less important, but they'll be kept in for showing-off purposes:

  1. "American" pinch

  2. "3-finger" pinch

  3. Palmar/Tray

  4. Hook

I also reordered direct motor control to be more intuitive (so it's easier for us to tune grasps).

1 - 3: thumb controls

4 - 7: bend finger joints

8: thumb mcp (not very useful)

9 - +: finger AB/AD (also not very useful)

values.description:
The initial arrangement of the demo world is now set to the first grasp task, ~~10cm~~ 5cm cube.

I made some small GUI changes so that the start button is enabled on startup and the initial task is checked (blue background).

I also added an "initial" tag to SDF to indicate the first task (previosly currentTaskId was set to 0, which conveniently worked because the initial task was task 0). @gerkey added some logic to make this more acceptable, although the possibility of a mismatched initial arrangement and task still remains.
values.title: Changed initial task, enabled button and set initial task checked

summary.raw:
The initial arrangement of the demo world is now set to the first grasp task, ~~10cm~~ 5cm cube.

I made some small GUI changes so that the start button is enabled on startup and the initial task is checked (blue background).

I also added an "initial" tag to SDF to indicate the first task (previosly currentTaskId was set to 0, which conveniently worked because the initial task was task 0). @gerkey added some logic to make this more acceptable, although the possibility of a mismatched initial arrangement and task still remains.
summary.html:
The initial arrangement of the demo world is now set to the first grasp task, 10cm 5cm cube.

I made some small GUI changes so that the start button is enabled on startup and the initial task is checked (blue background).

I also added an "initial" tag to SDF to indicate the first task (previosly currentTaskId was set to 0, which conveniently worked because the initial task was task 0). @gerkey added some logic to make this more acceptable, although the possibility of a mismatched initial arrangement and task still remains.

values.description: Previously, joint clamping was not implemented on the client side (GUI Plugin) for direct motor control (wrist ZXC or fingers after pressing ~). This means that after holding a button to increment a joint far past its joint limit, you would have to hold the button for a while to decrement it before making a change. This pull request should fix this behavior.
values.title: Implemented joint limit clamping on client side

summary.raw: Previously, joint clamping was not implemented on the client side (GUI Plugin) for direct motor control (wrist ZXC or fingers after pressing ~). This means that after holding a button to increment a joint far past its joint limit, you would have to hold the button for a while to decrement it before making a change. This pull request should fix this behavior.
summary.html: Previously, joint clamping was not implemented on the client side (GUI Plugin) for direct motor control (wrist ZXC or fingers after pressing ~). This means that after holding a button to increment a joint far past its joint limit, you would have to hold the button for a while to decrement it before making a change. This pull request should fix this behavior.

values.description: handsim was the only catkin repo. This PR eliminates the needs for catkin, fixes a bunch of warning messages, eliminates the need for a `setup.sh` file, adds in code_checking, and adds a place to put integration tests.
values.title: Change to a default CMake build

summary.raw: handsim was the only catkin repo. This PR eliminates the needs for catkin, fixes a bunch of warning messages, eliminates the need for a `setup.sh` file, adds in code_checking, and adds a place to put integration tests.
summary.html: handsim was the only catkin repo. This PR eliminates the needs for catkin, fixes a bunch of warning messages, eliminates the need for a setup.sh file, adds in code_checking, and adds a place to put integration tests.

values.description:
~~Review first:
[ign-transport PR #45](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-request/45/fixed-private-ip-return-on-determinehost/diff)~~ (merged)

This pull request enables Optitrack support for controlling the viewpoint and APL arm pose.

Optitrack: Receive NatNet UDP packets from a Windows machine running the Optitrack software, unpack the packets, and publish relevant pose information to Gazebo transport. Written by @caguero with a few tweaks by me, based on the public depacketization example in the [NatNet SDK](https://www.naturalpoint.com/optitrack/downloads/developer-tools.html#natnet-sdk).

Modifications to HaptixControlPlugin: Receive the pose of the Optitrack trackers on the computer monitor and on the user's head and arm. Calculates the corresponding viewpoint pose and APL arm base link pose, using the coordinate frame of the monitor as a reference point.

side note: If anyone's unhappy that the Optitrack class has hardcoded topic names and tracker names: I have grand plans to introduce a generalized Optitrack plugin into Gazebo6 (it's sitting in a branch untested). However, those plans are not time-sensitive and the Optitrack functionality is, so I'm holding of on that until now.
values.title: Optitrack support

summary.html:
Review first: ign-transport PR #45 (merged)

This pull request enables Optitrack support for controlling the viewpoint and APL arm pose.

Optitrack: Receive NatNet UDP packets from a Windows machine running the Optitrack software, unpack the packets, and publish relevant pose information to Gazebo transport. Written by @caguero with a few tweaks by me, based on the public depacketization example in the NatNet SDK.

Modifications to HaptixControlPlugin: Receive the pose of the Optitrack trackers on the computer monitor and on the user's head and arm. Calculates the corresponding viewpoint pose and APL arm base link pose, using the coordinate frame of the monitor as a reference point.

side note: If anyone's unhappy that the Optitrack class has hardcoded topic names and tracker names: I have grand plans to introduce a generalized Optitrack plugin into Gazebo6 (it's sitting in a branch untested). However, those plans are not time-sensitive and the Optitrack functionality is, so I'm holding of on that until now.
